data.text: Sawyer Water Filter System for Bike Touring

I’ve been reading a lot about people carrying water on their bikes despite the weight. I’m wondering if anyone has had luck carrying one of these instead ? Sawyer Products Squeeze Water Filtration System
Sawyer Products Squeeze Water Filtration System

Ideal for hiking, camping, hunting, fishing, emergency prep, or traveling abroad, Sawyer's Squeeze Water Filter ensures access to clean water in the backcountry or anywhere in the world. Rated to 0.1 micron absolute filtration, the Squeeze Filter removes 99.99999% of all bacteria such as salmonel...

amazon.com
Sawyers are great and good to have but it wouldn't be my primary. I'd just take the water weight and only go to the portable filter if absolutely necessary.
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: I’ve been using this filter for years while hiking. Can’t say enough good things. Check out the CNOC bag if you do get a Sawyer. They make a great pair.
data.author: Mike Hess

data.text:
https://www.rei.com/product/866422/platypus-gravityworks-water-filter-system-4-liter I always carry one of these, and its MUCH lighter than carrying enough water for my trips. On my recent trip in Vermont, I used it COUNTLESS times to refill along the way. I really recommend a gravity-type filter because it's just so much easier.
Platypus GravityWorks Water Filter System - 4 Liter | REI Co-op
rei.com
data.author: Chris Bussiere

data.text: Have the sawyer mini with a Gravity filter system using 2 cnoc vecto 3 litre bags so i can refill most water i carry at a time is about 3 litres for a day
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: I highly recommend this one. You fill it up and squeeze the water out. Very nice when filtering water for cooking or filling up your water bottle.
data.author: Carrie Everett

data.text: I’ve got the same one. Love it! Can’t recommend it enough.
data.author: Justin Zabrocki

data.text: love this one!! We carry two.
data.author: Patricia Roth

data.text: Sawyer Mini is the best. Learn how to backflush it
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: I've always taken a Sawyer mini filter system in case I needed to filter any water I collect from less than 'clean' sources. At times I've had to carry up to 10ltrs in a variety of containers and water bladders. In such situations it's too easy to forget to carry an extra 'clean water' container to pour the filtered water into! Also to remember to sterilise dirty water containers before reusing. Milton's baby bottle sterilising liquid is good for this.
data.author: Nick Paton

data.text: Always carry one.
data.author: Randall Munson

data.text: I have the Sawyer Mini. Smaller but less gallons than the Squeeze.
data.author: Robin Farris

data.text: Carry both. I go through a lot of water. Have run out of water before on a 100°+ day. Did not have a filter. Will never ride without one again. Some places it can be 40-50 miles between water.
data.author: Curtis Bunton

data.text: think there is a close to a 100 mile stretch in Wyoming.
data.author: Curtis Bunton

data.text: I use a sawyer as a back up, it's been a lifesaver more than once, I take it touring even if I don't use it
data.author: Graham Minshall

data.text: I carry a lot of water, a Sawyer AND a lifestraw. I know. I don't use the filters, as they're there for the Apocalypse.
data.author: Roger Komula

data.text: I carry a filtration system, but wild water is scarce where I’m touring now. I currently carry more than 4 gallons/ 16+ liters when I leave out, and have almost run out
data.author: Nesta Skychild

data.text: No water to filter in the Southwest US.
data.author: Martha Doran

data.text: We have both or Sawyer and befree water filters. However, it's not always easy to find water that you can filter. In my opinion, it is so much better to carry it on your bike instead of running out.
data.author: Patricia Roth

data.text: Think of the Sawyer or Aqua Mira, which is what I use, as a supplement to water you take with. On the AZT, north of Tucson, there is a section that has virtually no water for 45 miles of open desert. Lots of carry lots of water out in arid lands that do not apply to the rest of us with lakes and rivers everywhere. Regardless of climate or geography, having something like a sawyer is essential to being self supported.
data.author: Jeff Glessing

data.text: I keep a Sawyer and 2 Cnoc bladders with me. One clean one dirty. Typically use them more for hiking but on long rides it certainly doesn't hurt to know you can get water if needed.
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: Carry water purifier on trips , I don't buy bottle water , will not drink tape water unless purified or boiled . Very careful of quality of water I drink
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: I'm using another sawyer filter right now. There are ups and downs about it. Obviously you don't need to carry as much water when you have an idea of how much you'll need given a certain distance, but if you don't know when you'll find water again you need to load up as much as possible. The only other downside is that it takes a while to fill even the small 2 liter hydration pack that I carry. Other than that I would recommend carrying one even if you have water otherwise because you'll never know when you'll actually need it.
data.author: Patrick Kepler

data.text: I carry 2 3-liter bladders in a Fastback double century bag (on a recumbent) & use a Platypus gravityworks filter setup (4liter) to refill these with filtered water in place. Lotsa water onboard, but a similar setup might be adapted to a lower capacity bladder.
data.author: Will Taylor

data.text: I think you wanta have some storage - at least a liter, depending on availability of filterable water along your route & on the weather, using a filter to replenish a bladder or bottles as needed when running low. Can’t really count on filtering on the spot. Your need for water may not coincide with its availability. Also consider adding a charcoal secondary filter to deal with chemical impurities (agricultural runoff, &c.), unless you really crave Roundup® & nitrates, &c. in your drinking water.
data.author: Will Taylor

data.text: Sawyers are great and very popular with AT thru-hikers. For cycling, they make a good backup if you unexpectedly don't have access to potable water. You don't need to carry a lot of extra water, though, unless you're cycling in a dry area. Carry enough to get you to the next reilable source + maybe a half L extra.
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: I use powdered water
data.author: Grant P Dobson

data.text: The problem with a filter---which is a great idea if you are camping rough--is that you will not always have water to filter when you need water. In hot climates dehydration and even heat stroke are real issues. Absolutely carry all the water you will need .... the weight won't be an issue as you drink it, but not having it might leave you on the side of the road unable to proceed.
data.author: Chris Jasurek

data.text: The weight replaces what you lost! Much faster and safer to carry your own water then try to filter some unknown source.
data.author: Peter Breyfogle

data.text: I always figured that the water weight was either on me , or in me (at least till I used it up or sweated it out)so it didn't make any difference.
data.author: David Foster

data.text: Check out Katadyn BeFree - it’s smaller and lighter to carry!
data.author: Leah Frank

data.text: Water filter is always a great idea because water can run out quickly, especially in summer. Guess it depends an where you are and how controlled is any available water sources you come across as opposed to carrying it, you are your best doctor
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: I take mine everywhere I go. I use a Cnok bag with it. In Australia we still need to carry water in remote areas. My Sawyer filter comes in handy for waterholes, bores etc.
data.author: Ian Stapo

data.text: Yes, but swap the supplied bag for either a smartwater bottle or CNOC bag.
data.author: Kevin Smith

data.text: Probably matters where you’re riding? I was able to fill up my bottles by asking nicely or finding hoses/drinking fountains…
data.author: Cam Milleson

data.text: Yep/ Great for filtering town water to make it taste good. Occasionally have to use it to filter water from a stream, or filter water labelled BOIL. Never go without it. Very lightweight and worth its weight in gold, But I always try to carry 2 litres with me every morning.
data.author: Douglas Thompson

data.text: Yes I do
data.author: Jeff Flint

data.text: I’ve been using the Sawyer Squeeze for years now and it works great. Just back flush it once in a while and don’t let it freeze. Do NOT use the mini squeeze as it is a POS.
data.author: Craig Turner

data.text: I carry one and use as last resort emergency only. Just carry 1/2 a gallon with you and top off every chance
data.author: Joseph Delagarza

data.text: I use an MSR Trail Shot and carry about 3.5 liters.
data.author: Robin Brodsky
